entry.title: i18n & l10n — Internationalisation & localisation
entry.content:
The talk will be in french 🇫🇷 (but be sure we also speak English, don’t be shy and join us!).

SÃ©lectionnez votre pays. Quelle est votre langueâ€‰?

Sélectionnez votre pays. Quelle est votre langue ? Je veux que les chiffres soient formatés de cette manière. Quel est le fuseau horaire ? Je lis de droite à gauche.

Comment obtenez-vous ces informations de la part des gens ? Et comment donnez-vous ces informations aux gens qui viennent de différents pays et de différentes cultures ? Et que ces personnes parlent différentes langues…

La localisation et l’internationalisation sont des sujets complexes. Mais nous sommes là pour vous aider ! Prenez un moment pour voyager avec nous au pays du i18n et du l10n.

À propos de Marc & Guillaume

Marc est UX designer, usability engineer et aussi un peut frontend developper… Allez, disons que c'est un software designer ! Il a co-fondé l'agence Antistatique en 2008. C'est un adepte convaincu et convaincant du Web open-source, pour lequel il n'hésite jamais à apporter sa contribution. Il adore partager ses idées sur les méthodes de travail et sur la manière d'améliorer celui-ci. La conception centrée utilisateur est une seconde nature pour lui, là où la frontière entre code et design n'existe plus. Marc est aussi bénévole pour TEDx Lausanne.

Guillaume se tient au carrefour des pratiques du design. Directeur Artistique au sein d’Antistatique, toutes les formes d'art sont source d'inspiration pour lui. Il est toujours prêt à participer à des conférences, autant près de la maison qu'à l'étranger. Guillaume est méticuleux et travaille en véritable coéquipier. Il harmonise le temps et les contraintes d'un projet, ne manquant jamais d'ajouter une touche originale. Il est impliqué depuis 2011 dans l'association internationale IxDA (Interaction Design Association). Ah, et c’est aussi un fin gourmet !

entry.title: Designer pour le Sub/conscient
entry.content:
The talk will be in french 🇫🇷

Pourquoi le bouton BACK d’Android et l’autocorrect d’iOS sont incompatibles avec l’être humain?

Au travers cette présentation, je veux rappeler aux auditeurs le préambule de Jef Raskin dans son livre The Human Interface, en l’adaptant au concept mobile.

Je présenterai le concept du locus d’attention - le fait que notre esprit ne peut se focaliser que sur un seul objet cognitif à la fois, et décrire un certain nombre de conséquences, comme:

  • l’importance d’éliminer les fenêtres modales
  • la difficulté à luter contre les habitudes
  • l’aveuglement des notifications

Tous ces principes qui sont acquis par tous, mais ne sont jamais réellement challengés. Je veux expliquer pourquoi ils sont comme ça.

En recadrant les exemples dans un contexte mobile, où le locus d’attention n’est pas uniquement sur le terminal lui-même, mais inclut l’ensemble du contexte, j’espère donner conscience aux auditeurs de cette problématique qu’ils doivent garder en tête.

En sortant de cette séance pragmatique, l’auditeur aura appris ou se rappellera de ce concept important, à la base de nombreuses décisions de conception.

À propos de Gilles Demarty

De son passé de codeur, Gilles a gardé une chose, la rigueur. Difficile de mesurer une expérience? Il vous prouvera le contraire en appliquant des méthodes quantitatives et statistiques.

Le jour, il est UX Architect chez :ratio et la nuit il travaille au développement de l’association professionnelle de design d’interaction (IxDA). C’est également le cofondateur de UX Romandie, et de UX Lausanne. Comment fait-il pour encore garder de l’énergie pour tweeter, mitonner de bons petits plats et prendre des photos, c’est un mystère…

entry.title: Workshop: Accelerating UX
entry.content:
Accelerating UX: A Design Process For The Incubator Era

Workshop information

Language: English

Duration: 2 hours

Participants: 40 max. (first-come, first-served)

Price: Free

Important notice: As we have a limited number of seats, no Techup or other form this time. Please use the Tito. People subscribing to Techup will not be registered.

Workshop description

Banks, insurers, big telecommunication companies and others from the old economy feel they are under the threat of the young and dynamic. Fail-fast is a system at the core of the lean startup concept designed to make you learn and grow at unbelievable speed. Allianz SE, the world’s largest insurance company, has created an incubator to build startups and to iterate fast following the lean UX concepts. How can you design better products and services in this new era?

In this hands-on workshop attendees will be presented to a design challenge to be solved through the design of a mobile app. The speaker will show details on how an incubator works and innovates, the templates they use at Allianz X and provide sources of inspiration.

About Alexis Brion

Alexis Brion is the Innovation Lead at Allianz X, the startup incubator by Allianz. There he scouts for business ideas and mentors a variety of projects related to the financial world. Alexis lectures design innovation at the University of Applied Sciences Munich, taking students through a practical course in which they work on modern design innovation processes.

As a UX designer Alexis also gained in the last years experience introducing design processes into companies and leading big redesign projects, working at small and big internet companies.

entry.title: User-Centered Design Through Interdisciplinary Collaboration
entry.content:
The talk will be in english

At Studio Banana we believe in radical collaboration. It's the only way we know in order to deliver user-centered design products, services or experiences. We constantly explore new ways of fostering collaboration, from imagination workshops, to participatory user journeys, through crowdsourcing, crowd games and gamified challenges. In our gig at UX Romandie we'll explore some of these principles and discuss them with the public.

About Key Kawamura

Key Kawamura is co-founder of Studio Banana, an imagination agency based in Lausanne, Madrid and London. Active in the field of design-driven innovation, the studio's work includes acclaimed products like the Ostrich Pillow, crowdfunding landslides like Batband, upbeat work environments like the headquarters of McCann Worldgroup as well as work for multiple organisations. Studio Banana's work has been exhibited in museums like MoMA. Key, and his co-founding partner Ali, are frequent speakers in conferences and have lectured in places like Harvard, Stanford, Guggenheim Bilbao, Tokyo Designers Week or the Hong Kong Business of Design Week.

entry.title: Building a world class design team

link.title: Building a world class design team

entry.content:
The talk will be in english

With technology becoming a commodity, the last time Andy spoke at The Next Web, he explained how user experience was the next competitive battleground. Jump forward a couple of years and every start-up worth their series B has been investing in design; whether that’s hiring super star designers, commissioning world leading consultancies, or buying entire design studios. But how to you find the best talent, and, more importunely, how do you keep them? In this masterclass session, User Experience expert, Andy Budd, will outline the nine things you need to do to foster a healthy design culture, hire the right people, nurture talent and build a world class design team; in order to use design for your competitive advantage.

About Andy Budd

Andy Budd has been blogging about design and technology since 2003. He was one of the leading lights of the web standards movement and his book, CSS Mastery has sold over 60,000 copies and has been translated into a dozen languages. Andy has moved away from the development world over the last few years and is currently focused on the way people interact with technology.

Andy Budd is one of the founding partners at User Experience Design Consultancy, Clearleft. As a leading authority on interaction design, Andy is a regular speaker at international conferences like The Web 2.0 Expo, An Event Apart and SXSW. Andy curates dConstruct, one of the most popular design conferences in the UK. He's also responsible for UX London, the UK's first dedicated Usability, Information Architecture and User Experience Design event. Andy is the driving force behind Silverbackapp, a low cost usability testing tool for the Mac. He also plays a supporting role at Fontdeck, Clearleft's web type start-up.

entry.title: À la poursuite de l’utile
entry.content:
The talk will be in french

C'est en traçant une frontière artificielle dans le champ de la conception que le design bourgeois, autocentré et réalisé par et pour les designers que l'on se retrouve face à la question de l'utile. La place du design n'est pas gagnée. À quoi servira un typographe lors des grandes famines? Quel rôle un webdesigner peut-il avoir face au vieillissement de la population? Pourquoi étudier le design ethnographique à l'heure où le “big data” guide les entreprises? Les décisions des designers marquent notre monde comme autant de directions données à vivre à chacun. Ce sont ces directions qu'il faut questionner dès maintenant pour aller chercher l'utile afin de faire en sorte qu'il réinvestisse le champ du design.

À propos de Geoffrey Dorne

Designer graphique & numérique par formation, fondateur de sa société indépendante de design et chercheur par la pratique, Geoffrey Dorne est diplômé de l’École Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs de Paris (Ensad) en 2009.

Travaillant le numérique et l’imprimé sur des projets pour la Croix Rouge, la fondation Mozilla, Water Right Makers, la fondation Wikimedia, le Commissariat à l’Énergie Atomique, EDF, Samsung, Orange, des projets culturels pour Libération, la CNIL, diverses laboratoires de recherche, la Fonderie (l’agence numérique d’Île-de-France), ou encore les éditions Diateino, Geoffrey attache un intérêt particulier aux concepts, aux métaphores et à l’utilisateur.

En parallèle de ses activités, Geoffrey écrit quotidiennement sur son blog Graphism.fr et entreprend des projets de design autour de problématique humaines, sociales et contemporaines.

Aujourd'hui, Geoffrey s’engage totalement au travers de Design & Human et travaille avant tout pour la société avec des ONG, des entreprises, des associations tout en mettant en place des méthodologies centrées sur l’observation, sur l’utilisateur, sur l’humain.

entry.title: Increase Your (UX) Impact Through Collaboration
entry.content:
Finding the right balance between user needs, business needs and technical feasibility can sometime be challenging. This talk will discuss simple collaboration techniques you can use to make sure the voice of the user is fed into product's strategy.

By involving your stakeholders and team members throughout your design process, starting in its early stages, you will see them empathise more with users, and your ability to influence will increase. In addition, you’ll create shared understanding, which will make working with your colleagues much more enjoyable and productive. Finally working together as a multidisciplinary team, you’ll explore a greater multitude of ideas, and converge toward a better solution!

About Leo Marti

Leo is a data driven UX Designer, who loves to transform complex problems into simple and elegant solutions. Leo grew up in Geneva, but quickly left home to work across Europe and Asia. He worked on projects such as Indonesia's 1st music and movies streaming service, and a tool used by advertisement agencies to get legal feedback on every TV adverts aired in the UK. Leo is now a UX Designer at the BBC, where he practices Lean UX and strive to bridge the gap between Product Managers, Developers and Designers.

entry.title: The Innovation Myth
entry.content:
Innovation is the buzzword of the day. Big companies start innovation divisions, hire innovation managers and spend huge amounts of time and money on trying to make innovation happen. Do we actually know what we wish for, how we can achieve it and - why do we want it at all?

About Bastiaan van Rooden

When Bastiaan (@captspot) is not out and about in the Swiss Alps, you will find him designing digital products to make them simple, human and open. His first pixel was put on screen already in the 80s on an Amiga. In the meantime, he has become a diplomat in this universe, mediating between the planets Design and Development. Bastiaan's work made him travel the world to adventurous places like Russia and Algeria, but also lead him to design jobs for Wired or for Pixar to the Siggraph in L.A. In 1999, Bastiaan founded Nothing Interactive (@nothingagency), where he pools talents who create design which has been awarded several times.

entry.title: In Pursuit of Simplicity
entry.content:
Simplicity is the rallying cry that unites designers. We now live in the era of flat design, minimal interfaces, hamburger menus, and doppelganger websites. When we thought the three-click rule was dead, comes the two-tap rule.

But should simplicity be the ultimate goal? Design decisions aiming for reduction often introduce more friction and cognitive load, leading to a more complex user experience. Simple-looking products often carry hidden complexity. Simplicity can easily be a “neat, plausible, and wrong” solution to a problem.

Let's dive into the idea of simplicity and dissect it. Let’s have a look at what simplicity really means, whether it's really what people want, and how on Earth do we end up having complicated products.

About Zoltan Gocza

Zoltan (@goczazoltan) is a user experience and product development guy. He loves working at the intersection of data and gut instinct. Fights design myths and contrast criminals. Not too bad at 8-bit games either.

Zoltan leads the UX team at Centralway, set out to redefine mobile banking. Before joining Centralway, he was head of UX at the communication agency Isobar, and at Ustream, the leader in live video. He co-founded one of the leading Hungarian daily deal aggregators.

entry.title: UX in a time of emerging technologies

link.title: UX in a time of emerging technologies

entry.content:
We’re in a period where, each day, we’re seeing more and more of what was recently science fiction alive within the reality of our everyday world. Smartphones that resemble Star Trek tricorders. MIT’s stealth cheetah robot that looks like it leaped straight from the latest Hollywood blockbuster into our real world. Drones that drop bombs on one continent even while they deliver consumer goods to citizens’ front doors on the other. We’re getting a glimpse into the future, and it is one that will shake the foundations of user experience. User experience (UX) as a discipline started in computer hardware and software, was co-opted and accelerated by website design, and is returning to roost in the exploding digital products of today and tomorrow.

These products differ mightily from the simple and screen-based technologies that was the domain of UX. They synthesize multiple cutting-edge scientific fields. For example, as the internet of things turns us into the everyday cyborg, huge industries will form that require deep knowledge of natural biology, synthetic biology, genomics, robotics, and material sciences, Oh, and computer science, which used to be the only crunchy scientific field we needed to worry about at all!

Where does user experience fit into this picture? That’s up to us but, to remain relevant, we will need to learn, adapt, and grow in ways we never would have imagined when learning about research, interaction design, and javascript.

About Dirk Knemeyer

Dirk is the founder and Chairman of Involution Studios, a user experience agency specializing in designing software for emerging technologies. Under Dirk’s leadership, Involution Studios has designed or redesigned major software applications for a client list that includes Apple, Microsoft, Oracle, Shutterfly, PayPal, and the administration of U.S. President Barack Obama.

Dirk is a futurist who specializes in the relationship between technology, markets, and human behaviour. He has published more than 100 articles in publications such as Business Week; given more than 50 speeches and presentations, including conference keynotes in Europe and the United States; and has participated on the boards of 15 organizations that include a secondary school, a wellness center, and various design and software organizations. Projects that Dirk led or contributed to have won top honors across every communication medium—including Webby, Telly and Addy awards—and a variety of vertical industries.
